cd374f14-6878-401e-b339-d9c6a18d9244.description: Successful participants should be able to: 1. Design, develop, and deliver units of instruction that meet the instructional needs of the audience, adhere to the principles of instructional design, and engage learners. 2. Create assessments that measure the learner’s mastery of the intended learning objectives 3. Engage in self-reflection and self-assessment which results in performance improvement 4. Articulate a teaching philosophy 5. Create and maintain a teaching portfolio.
cd374f14-6878-401e-b339-d9c6a18d9244.name: Teaching & Learning Certificate Program

issuer.summary: issued by The University of Mississippi Medical Center

entity.name: The University of Mississippi Medical Center

badge_template_activities.title: Participate in the TLC Program seminar series.
Write a 800-1200 word blog essay regarding a technique/strategy/innovation that informs teaching and learning.
Write a teaching philosophy statement.

Create at least one comprehensive lesson plan for a learning activity (e.g. skills lab, APPE student discussion, online CE program) or create at least one syllabus. The lesson plan or syllabus must include learning objectives and an assessment.
Assist with the implementation of at least one skills-based learning activity (e.g. skills lab, IPE exercise) and write a reflective essay about the experience.

Author at least one case. This may be either one mini-case OR updating one progressive disclosure case for PBL Group or an Integrated Systems course. In addition to developing the case materials, draft the learning objectives and assessments associated with the case.

Facilitate (independently) at least six group sessions. For PBL Group on the Jackson campus, this will require attending an orientation meeting and co-facilitating sessions prior to independently facilitating PBL Group. Write a reflective essay about the experience.

Design, develop, and deliver at least two (2) presentations of at least 30-minutes in duration that include active learning elements. These presentations may be given to any audience (e.g. health professional students, health professionals, pharmacy technicians, or patients), but at least one presentation must be approved for continuing education credit. Write a reflective essay about the experience.
Develop and grade at least one instructional activity.
Develop at least ten (10) exam questions (e.g. Problem-Solving Exam, Knowledge and Comprehension Exam, or course-specific exam).
Co-precept at least one pharmacy student on either an IPPE or APPE. Draft the student's midpoint and end-of-experience evaluations. Write a reflective essay about the experience.
Create and maintain a teaching portfolio.

3d6351ad-c0b0-47ec-886d-bfb15f9cba72.description: This is a professional, interactive lecture series that aims to engage earners in professional development through personal wellness. Earners must attend 4 out of 5 seminars centered around translating personal development into applicable, professional skills.

issuer.summary: issued by The University of Mississippi Medical Center

entity.name: The University of Mississippi Medical Center

badge_template_activities.title: Earners must accept an invitation to a Canvas course provided by the Office of Student Affairs so that they may access Nearpod activities as well as submit pre- and post-session surveys.

Earners must attend 4 out of 5 seminars. Topics include: Professional and Personal Identity and Goal Setting; Self-care, self-worth, and supportive relationships; Substance misuse and prevention; mental health, burn-out, and imposter syndrome; Lifestyle and physical health.

Assessments include: Pre-course survey: Gauge participants’ comfort & understanding of the topics; Pre-Session Survey: Assess comfort with & knowledge of each topic to establish a baseline to assess session benefits; Post-Survey: Assess comfort with & knowledge of each topic to measure changes in student professional development after participation; End of course survey: Assess changes in understanding of & confidence to program topics.

6bf0f65d-7261-478b-bc08-d971c6345e0d.description: It is necessary for students at Jackson Free Clinic to draw blood. JFC is staffed by volunteer students who provide medical services under supervision. Volunteer students receive initial phlebotomy training at M1 Orientation, but most students have little ability & confidence to perform the procedure well. The goals of this course are: 1) improve the students' procedural skills; 2) increase the student's confidence in phlebotomy to improve patient safety and satisfaction at JFC.
6bf0f65d-7261-478b-bc08-d971c6345e0d.name: Phlebotomy

issuer.summary: issued by The University of Mississippi Medical Center

entity.name: The University of Mississippi Medical Center

badge_template_activities.title: The "flipped classroom model" is used to deploy didactic information. A slide show is used that includes background information, preparation, steps of phlebotomy, documentation, safety, and troubleshooting. The students receive access to the slide show when they sign up for the hands-on session and are instructed to review the information.
Hands-on sessions are scheduled online, on a voluntary basis. A group of students will participate in a 30-min session and they are instructed by one or two instructors.

Each student is required to perform a successful phlebotomy on 2 different skin color arms, under the instructor's supervision. They are provided with sterile supplies to practice in pairs including tourniquet placement and therapeutic talk.

badge_template_activities.title: Earners must attend the panel discussion titled: Interprofessional Perspective and Review of the COVID-19 Vaccines Development and Rollout. Core IPE competency addressed is Roles and Responsibilities for Collaborative Practice. Learning objectives include: Identify roles of various healthcare and health-related professions in developing and administrating COVID-19 vaccines; Explain each role; and Reflect on the successes and failures of the rollout from the perspectives of each role.

Earners must respond to a reflection assignment regarding the following questions. Healthcare and health-related professions often set health examples intentionally and unintentionally. What are some ways healthcare and health-related professions can set a positive example with respect to COVID-19 vaccines? Do healthcare and health-related professionals have an obligation to be vocal proponents in media? How can health care professionals assist in improving the rollout and address challenges?

ade5305b-aa51-43a0-9f71-3b3489454b2e.description: In BaFa’ BaFa’, participants understand the powerful effects culture plays in every person’s life by experiencing it themselves. It may help prepare for living & working in another culture or how to work with people from other departments, disciplines, genders, races, & ages. Participants become aware of how these differences impact the behavior of people in an organization & gain insight into how stereotypes are developed, barriers created, and misunderstandings magnified.
ade5305b-aa51-43a0-9f71-3b3489454b2e.name: Cross Culture, Diversity & Inclusion

issuer.summary: issued by The University of Mississippi Medical Center

entity.name: The University of Mississippi Medical Center

badge_template_activities.title: Participants are provided with a safe vehicle to discuss the ways cultural, physical and racial differences affect others as well as themselves. The simulation experience helps participants prepare for living and working in another culture.
Implicit bias assessment; The simulation has a gamification component between two communities (Alphans and Betans); Large group debrief of experience; Brief reflective writing submission

Over the course of the simulation event, participants will: 1) Explore how cultural bias affects cultural perception; 2) Reflect on bias within themselves, communities, and each other; 3) Describe how themes of cultural perception, cultural polarization, and sensitivity in intercultural communication can impact culture, language, beliefs & values.

9ce4a010-6426-4323-94a4-5d8293caf9da.description: A central line-associated bloodstream infection (CLABSI) is a laboratory-confirmed bloodstream infection not related to an infection at another site that develops within 48 hours of central line placement. Most cases are preventable with proper aseptic techniques, surveillance, and management strategies. The occurrence of CLABSI influences a hospital’s patient safety rating. This course will train new instructors at UMMC.

dfe85e2c-8d79-4abb-9630-3d2f77bd0a9c.description: Professional, interactive lecture series that aims to engage earners in professional development through personal wellness; centered around translating personal development into professional skills. badge_template_activities.title: Earners must accept an invitation to a Canvas course provided by the Office of Student Affairs so that they may access Nearpod activities as well as submit pre- and post-session surveys.

Assessments include: Pre-session, post-session, and post program surveys. Surveys are administered via Canvas to communicate with participants, upload resources, and allow group discussion. Adequate participation in group exercises will be required for credit for completing the program.
